Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of nano-CT-based elastography system for three-dimensional deformation field and elastic characterization of heterogeneous materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the development of a nano-CT-based elastography system that will permit three-dimensional (3-D) reconstruction of deeply embedded local details of a deformation field with sub-micron resolution and the associated characterization of images to generate anisotropic modulus elastograms. With the integration of a nano-CT adaptive compression wave generator, the system can unveil a significant amount of hidden information regarding the localized deformation and mechanical distribution within materials. The unique combination of milimeter-scale penetration length with sub-micron resolution offered by nano-CT makes it an ideal tool for noninvasive 3-D mechanical deformation imaging.

If successful, the development for the elastography system will enhance the overall capabilities for micro-/nano-systems development and materials characterization. Furthermore, the proposed development will enable exciting educational activities both at the undergraduate and graduate level, in all five engineering departments at UC Irvine. This interdisciplinary nature of the project will also help attract and retain students from underrepresented groups and expose them to the state-of-the-art research. The project will disseminate its findings broadly through submission of publications, presentations in conferences, and non-technical publications through the internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the support of NSF, we acquired a state-of-the-art nano-CT and developed a nano-CT-based elastography system that permits three-dimensional reconstruction of deeply embedded local details of deformation data with sub-micron resolution and the associated characterization of images to estimate how stiff the material components are in their microstructures. Specifically, with the integration of a nano-CT adaptive compression wave generator, the system can unveil a significant amount of hidden information regarding the localized deformation and mechanical stiffness distribution within materials. The developed nano-CT elastography system makes it an ideal tool for noninvasive multi-dimensional mechanical deformation imaging. It can enhance the overall capabilities for materials characterization at micro-/nano-length-scales and can be applied to multidisciplinary research fields from civil infrastructure to brain imaging. It is among the first efforts to develop such CT-based system to characterize the material mechanical properties at sub-micron length scales in US universities.

The broader impacts are that the development for the elastography system offers a unique opportunity that will project US research institutions to the top of this fast-growing research field. Furthermore, it enables exciting educational activities and training of next generation of researchers. Specifically this state-of-the-art development has provided the graduate students with an efficient, user-friendly and nondestructive tool to understand and unveil the micro structural world of materials. We also have created outreach activities by participating in engineering exhibitions and demonstrations on UCI campus attracting hundreds of high school and college students, scholars, and professionals.
